description.text:
I designed a traveling box for Chess to fit in a pocket. It's roughly 80x80mm.
The cover 'clicks' on the top of the board, so the position of pieces is saved during travel.
It clicks on the bottom of the board as well and has a hole in it to store captured pieces.

The pieces are modified, based on a design of Mikey77
All is designed and modified in ArchiCad 17

I have printed it in PLA, 0.2mm LH in black and white.
-2x the set pieces (in both white and black)
-1x the cover and playing field in white
-32x the tiles in black.

I have glued some foam inside the cover, to prevent the pieces to fall out during travel.
The tiles should exactly fit in the board and can be glued in.

comments.text: The only issue with the design is the hole on the side lets things slip out-I'm going to see if I can make a plug to put in it
comments.author: rmeskill

A mount to hold a prop balancer setup.  Keeps the total cost in the $4 range for a prop balancer instead of around $40.  
Simply insert 8mm diameter magnets into the eyelets and position prop balancer in between.

comments.text: What is the maximum size of the props?
comments.author: McNugget

comments.text: It's around 8-9" props easily, but for larger props you have to lay the balancer flat over the edge of a table when you do the front and back balance (with the prop up and down - as the blade that hangs down would bump the base).  I've done a 14" prop this way, however, if I went much bigger and the prop might be too heavy for the balancer magnets.
comments.author: McNugget

comments.text: Nice design!  Where would I found the mounts for the props?
comments.author: mbradley

comments.text: I put two 8mm diameter magnets into the eyes of the rig then I put them on one of the great planes 'hand prop balancers' (it's about $5) http://www.greathobbies.com/productinfo/?prod_id=GPMQ5000http://www.greathobbies.com/pr... between the two magnets.
comments.author: mbradley

comments.text: Thanks!

I liked caswal's design and give him all the credit. However, I was bothered by the amount of plastic between chambers. This design is my attempt to reduce the thickness of the walls by incorporating magnets as a way to attach the modules.

Printed standard quality. Depending on your printer and materials, you may want to use supports for the square hole. Just be sure to tweak the program so it doesn't build supports in the inside holes or you will have to dig them all out. I did once, and it was kind of a pain. I used 1mm acrylic for the lid which gave me room to print a cover (to keep the queen in the dark) using caswal's design. I used 8mm x 3mm neodymium magnets purchased online.

comments.text: I really like this concept, ants are so sensitive to movement and adding or changing formicarium parts can cause significant stress, so this might help reduce that impact considerably.

comments.text: Thanks, it works well.  Honestly, my initial goal was to reduce the amount of plastic obstructing the view between chambers.

description.text:
This car was designed in Fusion 360. I printed one on my Printrbot Simple. It fits on the standard wooden tracks of common kids train sets i.e. Brio and Ikea.

Rough dimensions after assembly:
-3 in. tall
-3.5 in. long
-1.5 in wide

Note: Superglue will be needed.

Inches were used as the units for this model. I printed my parts using Repetier, and I had to scale the model by 25.4, (1 in = 25.4 mm). You may have to do the same depending on your printing software.

Print the following:
-One Car_Body
-Four Car_Wheel(s)
-Four Car_Rims (print vertically)

Assembly: Stick one of the "rims" through one of the wheels so that the hub/end-stop is on the side of the wheel with the indentation. Apply some superglue to the flat part of the axle and stick it through the hole in the car. Perform the same steps with another rim and wheel, and try to arrange the flat ends against each other. Hold until dry.

title: GEEETech MK8 Printhead Fan Shroud ver.3 (compact)

description.text:
A revised version of my GeeeTech Prusa i3 Acrylic print cooler duct that mounts to the MK8 Extruder -

My MK8 extruder came with a cooling block that had the heat sink fins running in a vertical direction - but I have had several requests to make a version for the heat sink with horizontal fins - This version #2, will work well with the fins in either direction - directing the air from the heatsink fan to the blower ducts and using it as a print/filament cooler.

This keeps the system very compact and light.

*UPDATE (9/19/2015): Added updated version that has the LED mounting holes if you want LED's on your cooler (illuminates the print) like my ver 2.0 but now for a vertical or horizontal heatsink. The LED's x4 direct light around the nozzle so I don't need to find a flashlight every time I want to see how my print is doing or to inspect/clean my nozzle.

LED's I used are: BCMD204UWC (3200mcd, 3mm, 3.2Vf @20mA - 25Viewing Angle) actual measurements are 3.1mm diam with a 3.8mm diam lip at the very top x 6.3mm in length, 3.3v, set in the mounts with silicone or epoxy at the top of each bulb, hooked up in series then directly to the 12v power supply with a separate on/off switch (see my other things for the switch box) -

Please post pics of your makes of this item and comment if you have ideas to make it better - THANKS ALL !!!
created in sketchup, then checked in netfab for manifold

Filament Spool Holder designed in solidworks. You can print in one piece if your printer can fit it or print in separate pieces. The cut out on the top fits a .25 inch piece of tubing like I have used or anything you have. I super glued the separate pieces together and they seem to be holding up. Should hold the spool off the surface enough to spin freely. Also worked well with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:436112.

Unfortunately my printer wasn't big enough to print the whole piece at once so I had to cut it in half and scale it down and by doing that the height was off which explains why there is a block underneath it. Its big enough to raise the spool off the surface to spin freely.

Measured width of filament spool, then measured distance from surface and center of spool holder to figure out height of stand. Its about .25 of an inch off the surface and able to spin freely. Took my measurements to solidworks and this is what I came up with.

description.text:
This is a corner riser to elevate your Power Macintosh G4 Cube by one inch. You'll want to print four, one for each corner.

The G4 Cube is convection-cooled, but normally only takes in air at the back. Raising it with these corner risers means you get air intake at all four sides.

The extra vertical space underneath also makes the ports and programmer's switch on the bottom of the computer easier to access without having to turn the computer over.
I wrote the model in OpenSCAD (model source attached), sliced it in Simplify3D, and printed it on a PowerSpec Pro printer in PLA.

author: alumin

title: Wanhao duplicator i3 <=V1 - Glass bed XY corner clamp

description.text:
Many people have advised that this does not fit the V2 of the wanhao duplicator i3. Be wary, and use a remix of this design if you have that printer. I don't have a wanhao i3 any more so won't be making a replacement.

Little clamps to locate your glass bed in the XY axis'.

Per clamp, you'll need:

  • 2x M3 bolt or grub screw (minimum 10mm thread length)
  • 2x M3 nut (or M3 tap)
  • [OPTIONAL] Thermally isolating M3 washer - I used a glass fibre washer, but nylon, rubber, or similar will be fine.

Your bed does need to be disassembled to install this, as the clamp is bolted into place through the riser bolts that hold the bed to the Y carriage.

If you've made the (highly recommended) M3 nyloc nut mod to the bed levelling bolts, they are used to secure the clamp in the Z axis. If not, use the levelling spring, but it may wear as it is tightened and loosened over time.

I also recommend you print this in ABS, due to thermal properties and to avoid warping when your bed gets to temp.

comments.text: One more heads up for v2.1 owners - the clips site higher than my print surface, even with a silicon mat and a glass plate. This results in the cooling fan on the front of the extruder hitting the front two clips, while in the back, if the y axis is fully homed or extended, and the bed pulled forward, the nozzle will melt the clips. It's not a huge deal if you remember it, and don't print in the far corners of the bed, which I haven't found much need to do, besides leveling tests.
comments.author: Dakine83

comments.text: It sounds like your glass is shorter than it should be for this mod.
comments.author: Dakine83

comments.text: Great little mod! Any chance of getting a version of this that will fit nylock nuts instead of plain nuts? My prints jerk the glass loose 2-3 times per print. Also, like bbbbbb said, this does not fit the v2.1 maker select bed without drilling a new hole in the printed parts.
comments.author: Dakine83

comments.text: Just to update my comment for anyone else reading this - The glass doesn't jerk loose any more. What happened is the clips aren't a perfect fit for the v2.1 bed, and as a result, they rotate around the bed screw. I found that tightening the set screws, then rotating the clip a bit back and forth a bit and tightening more eventually gets it set quite nicely.
comments.author: Dakine83

comments.text: Printed and installed these on my Maker Select v2.1. Used ABS filament. The hole was a fair bit too far out (needed to be closer towards the middle of the machine) and had to be drilled a fair bit just to align correctly. It additionally had to be drilled out to fit over the piece of plastic v2.1 has that helps keep the spring in position. Ideally I think you'd remove this plastic bit, install the corner clamp, then replace the plastic bit under the corner clamp. The plastic bit wasn't coming off easily for me and I didn't want to break it, so I just drilled out the bed clamp hole to be big enough to fit around it. It renders the plastic bit a bit useless but whatever, seems to be working.

author: adam_th

description.text: Need to connect two parts semi-permanently? This might be the thing to use, Just substract pill_sub()(pill_sub.stl) on the two parts to connect, compress, and pop the 'cylinder pill'(fat_pill if you want it to be tighter) in, and then pop the other part on that. This entry contains the pill and pill_sub as development aid. Place of development is currently github. (Also released on fabfabbers.)

The pills need to be printed with zero infill, zero bottom and top layers, and one perimeter.(at ~0.5mm, if you lay out a particularly small perimeter, you may want more) Pills are used on designs by substracting pill_sub halfway at places on the two parts in such a way they line up the way you want them. The beams are not intended to hold an angle by themselves. They're mostly an illustration on how to use them at the moment.(though you could use them as.. beams for something)

This is my second wing, and - it even flies :-)
Even a looping, not really round but for the beginning not so bad: http://youtu.be/XIrR3X5ENus
Here is another video which is made by a friend. He added some videos of printing some parts of the plane and some stills of the preparing for the flight - and a wonderfull music that makes you feel as if the plane hovers almost weightless in the sky :-)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ut_Ei22on58 This wing has straight middle sections, so that the carbon tubes can go through. That makes them much more stronger in that section which is especially loaded.
Here affects the maximum bending moment.
I pushed this problem more to outside, where the bending moment is much less.
I designed new wing sections for those critical points. It has a structural infill that makes this parts much stronger and even pretty light.
The wingspan is 1600 mm, 50 mm more than my first wing which I published before: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:86982 And now - one year later, I finished my big aerobatic wing plane: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:407766
and
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:453090

The methode to build the wing is the same as to the first wing.
Just print the rest wing sections in sizes you prefer and and of course the wingtips.
Besides of the middle sections you need 2x 450 mm and 2x 270 mm of wing sections. Carbon Tubes
1x 8/6 mm (outer/inner diameter) x 1000 mm long - (for the middle wing)
1x 8/6 mm (outer/inner diameter) x 307 mm long - (for the wing end sections) 1x 4/3 mm (outer/inner diameter) x 1000 mm long - (for the middle wing)
2x 4/3 mm (outer/inner diameter) x 297 mm long - (for the wing end section)

title: DEVO 7E / Turnigy 9X / Taranis FPV Monitor/RX/Battery Mount

description.text:
A base for holding a FPV LCD monitor kit for the awesome DEVO 7E.
Quick attachment to the antenna collar. It is designed to hold a compact RX5832 receiver, a 3S 850mAH battery and a 5" LCD monitor.

Originally designed for the DEVO 7E. It will also fit the Turnigy 9X with a little filing of the antenna base rings.

Fits the Frsky Taranis without modification.

Print one of each part.

Assemble with three M3 nuts and three M3, 14mm thumb screw. I used: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__37437__Canopy_Thumb_Screw_M3x18mm_2pcs_.html

Use gray 3M double side tape to attach the LCD to the pack.

Receiver source: http://www.banggood.com/5_8G-600mW-32CH-2s6s-DC-Image-Transmission-RX5832-Receiver-For-Multicopter-FPV-p-985687.html

To mount it to the Turnigy 9X, the antenna base rings need to be modified a bit. The DEVO 7E rings are oval, but the Turnigy 9X rings are round, with the same maximum diameter. You need to do a bit of filing to the front and back side of the rings to make it oval. Mask the area around the rings with masking tape to prevent any accidental marring of the transmitter. Take a flat file and carefully file the rings to match the profile of the mounting collar. Very little plastic needs to be removed.

Use PIR sensor like so
https://learn.adafruit.com/pir-passive-infrared-proximity-motion-sensor/overview
Position the sensor and then drill the holes to fit those on the IC board of the PIR.

The bona fide Pi NoIR camera like so
https://www.raspberrypi.org/products/pi-noir-camera/

IR LEDs on normal perfboard (skip 'n column between LEDs then the spacing will be fine). I use 5mm LEDs. Needed to drill holes after print to widen them further with 5.5mm drill.

The Autodesk 123D file is also uploaded so you can patch up the holes if not needed but they're supposed to allow for external power and ethernet if the trail happens to be in your home.

Use printer with heated bed only as everything needs to print perfectly flat if you want it to close tight.

title: Da Vinci 3D Printer 1.1 Extruder MK8 modification

description.text:
Da Vinci MK8 Extruder modification. This mod will allow you to print PLA and ABS without a problem. It uses the original extruder motor so you can run this using the original firmware.

Modification details:

  1. Print the required 3 parts.
  2. Remove the original extruder and motor.
  3. Insert the rubber filament into the provided hole in the ex holder.
  4. You will need to cut down the smaller of the filament tubes to it fits a little.
  5. Reverse the extrude motor wires. This is required as the extruder now sits on the otherside. So if the wires were 1.2.3.4 they need to be 4.3.2.1. I used a pin to pull the wires out of the extruder connector and inserted them back in. No soldering is required here.
  6. I also used the original heating element and temp component, you can swap these around. You will need to rotate the extruder head so it then fits into the original carriage.
  7. Screw everything back together and clip the X axis clip on to realign the head so it self cleans again.

Quite a simple mod, I wouldn't say it's that difficult and it's great being able to print PLA without a problem.

Please see my other mod of a touchscreen cartridge resetter for this printer.

comments.text: What is the advantage of the MK8 over the stock setup?  Just trying to figure out what the draw is for the MK8 vs the factory or J-Heads.
comments.author: DarkTreader

comments.text: Hi, you can not print 3d party PLA with the standard head. It transfers heat up the hot end and tends to pre-melt the PLA and cause a blockage. Some people have added heat sinks and reversed the fan but I just couldn't get it to be reliable at all. I had a spare mk8 knocking around so thought I would give it a go. The MK8 doesnt have a long hotend where the J-Head tends to be quite a long unit. I think if you used the J-Head you may need to adjust your Z axis.
comments.author: DarkTreader

comments.text: doe's XYZ PLA have a higher melting point?   you mentioned in a post that all that is really needed is the center part, did you mean the (gold) assy and extruder.  Is there a reason to keep the end of the feed tube up high? I"ve seen some of the MK8's with the tube connector actually on the golden assy. vs. suspended above,   thanks for your great comments and info.  also off topic do you have any issue with wiggle in the bed from the back threaded rod not being supported at the top?
comments.author: CdRsKuLL

comments.text: Hi, no PLA has a lower melting point be you still get heat creeping up the hotend. I think the MK8 has a PTFE lined hotend which protects it for this heat creep. I think PLA must expand or something which causes it to stick / block. With the standard hotend it was able to print the first layer but get stuck after that. It was a nightmare then trying to remove it.. caused hours of frustration trying to clean it all out.  I've not noticed a wiggle from the back threaded rod but I've not looked to be honest so it might suffer from it. I run my PLA prints at 55 bed / 185 hotend. This then means once finished printing the bed lowers immediately.. Also you don't get much shrinkage like ABS.   I think they are now moving the motor off the X axis to above.. is this called a bowden something? I can only presume they are doing this to reduce the weight on the X / Y axis so you can print faster maybe? I'm not sure how this effects the measured amount of filament mind.
comments.author: DarkTreader

comments.text: Have you tried any of the newer materials yet? like glow/flexible and the such?  also have you needed a cooling fan to work the PLA. and last question, with this mod, is the calibration feature lost?
comments.author: DarkTreader

comments.text: Hi, not tried any other than PLA / ABS sorry. I'm using the standard hotend cooling fan but nothing else and I've printed lots of PLA without a problem now (5 rolls).
comments.author: DarkTreader

comments.text: Can you please post some additional photos showing where the existing hot end attaches with this mod.   Not sure how or where the brace attaches.  Hard to tell from your photos due the wires being in the way.  It also looks like you are using a heat sink for the fan/extruder.  A parts list of what you purchased for the mod would be nice.
comments.author: Flashsolutions

comments.text: Hi sorry, just seen this post.  I'm using the original fan but using the heatsink off the mk8 hotend. I swapped out the mk8 heating element fo the original one and also the heat sensor. So the only bits I used on the mk8 is the hotend / heatsink and the aluminium orange bit in the photo. Let me know if you still need more pic's

comments.author: Victhor

description.text:
Note... after some consideration Ive decided to do a mk2 of this that will feature a retainer for the races and be 100% printed, ie no steel balls

Horizontal filament holder for a delta printer, This was designed specifically for the RepRapPro Fisher but would be suitable for others, especially if they have a flat top suitable to put the filaments on.

Essentially this is a thrust bearing design, and in fact can be used for a wide range of applications where something needs to rotate.

Need a Lazy Susan for your dinner party?.... just put a plate on top of this and your golden.

Want to rotate a heavy object? pop one of these under it and it will spin like very easily

The completed assembly requires two races to be printed and uses 1/2" balls, the ball spacer is optional and just makes it possible to use less balls, if you end up using this for heavy loads then maybe remove the spacer and fill the race with as many balls as you can.

Before a reel is placed on top you will also need a Spigot, most reels have an indented feature that can take a spigot, Ive included the two spigots for the reels I currently use, but its easy to make more with the most basic of CAD packages.

Its also possible to stack your unused filaments on top of each other by making spigots that can key one reel to the other, however take care not to overload your printer top of make the stack so high it becomes unstable.

This uses 1/2" balls but can easily be scaled for any size, you need two of the race parts.
Early versions of this used more balls and worked fine, the spacer is a new mod, less balls means less rolling resistance, but also less load capacity.

The spigots are spool specific the smaller on is suitable for a Sun Filament spool, the larger one is for a 1kg spool brand unknown.

Just a nice little chassis for a small tank with various scavenged parts. I used parts I got of ebay, a local fleamarket and a cheap toy boat for the transmitter and receiver.

Also good to use with different electronics or as a robot platform.

http://youtu.be/FrUpXXnwqTk to see it driving for a bit.

Currently I am designing a tank with a proper RC remote, two 400 rpm motors, and ESC's and threads I bought from aliexpress and smaller bearings. But awaiting the parts for it.

Parts list:

  • Electronics from a cheap RC boat with two motors.
    (a bit like this Allthough mine used 4 AA: www.bartsmit.com/nl/bsnl/waterspeelgoed-1/op-afstand-bestuurbare-boot-sea-lord-34-cm )
  • 2 x 25 mm diameter 200 RPM @12 volt DC motors
  • 2 x 5mm Bore Electrical Car Toy Motor Wheel Coupler
  • 2 x rubber caterpillar tracks I bought for €0,50 at a flea market
    (I have no idea where they came from)
  • 2 x 18650 battery
  • M8 thread rod 180 mm
  • 4 x M8 Nut
  • 4 x 608 bearing
  • 4 x M3 bolt
  • 8 X M3 nut
  • 8 x 3.5 x 30 woodscrews (a bit shorter is better)
    Some wires.

I ripped the toy boat apart en cut of the motorpod so I got 4 wires dangling from a 4 x 4 cm electronics board with an antenna and 2 wires (one with switch) for the battery.

Print both chassis parts and glue them together. I used hotglue. Next drill the axle hole for the M8 rod and screw it in and lock it in place with two nuts.
Print the front wheels and push in the 4 608 bearing and put them on the M8 rod at both sides and put nuts on it to lock them in place. Do not over tighten or you'll bind the bearings.

Print the engine clamp and drill out the holes with a 4 mm drill.
Next drill the holes in the back of the chassis with a 3 mm drill.

Print the 18650 battery holder twice, drill out the holes with a 3 mm drill put in the M3 screws with the head on the inside and a nut on the outside. Connect two terminals at one end together and use the terminals at the other end as a + and - connector and connect the wires with the M3 nuts. Put in the cells and be careful not to blow them up because the polarity is wrong ;) Apply a bunch of rubber bands to keep the battery holder closed. (It's ugly but it'll work, it ain't called lazy one for nothing)

Solder the wires onto the electric motors and hook up your power supply for a test.

Put the couplers on the motors and the printed drive wheels onto the couplers.

Then add the threads to it and it is time to test while both the lids are printing. (where I am now) The lids don't properly fit at the moment. These need some work yet. :)

I live somewhat excluded at the end of a long, raised power line. This means that autumn thunderstorms often cuts the power, sometimes for a day or two. So I have a Lister backup generator.

To monitor the electricity I bought dials for current, voltage and frequency on ebay. I think they look nice in this box, and yes, I was inspired by Roberto from Futorama.

I also made a box for switches and dials to start/stop and monitor the engine remotely.

The generator in the picture actually belong to my brother, but it is the same type as mine.

title: Expandable Workbench Tool Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing is a tool holder for electronics workbenches. It is designed to be expandable to as many bays as needed, and the top panel can be changed in each bay to fit your tool needs.  
more expansion kits will be coming. The first revision is a little small, but functional. I will think of some modifications and post more expansion kits.   
Update 2: Revision 2 is posted, but not yet tested. The bottom of R2 trays are designed to be large enough for square Post-it notes.  
I also added an insert box that works with R2.  
Update 2.1: I cut the parts for R2, and found a few small errors. R2.1 is now posted with the corrections.

laser cut as many bays as you want out of 3mm material. The starter stand includes 3 bays and 4 side walls.  
The solder tool stand has a solder spool holder built into the side walls, and a custom front pane for the solder to exit from. It also includes two options for the top tool holder.  
Glue together and optionally add feet. See pictures for assembly process.  . If you want to expand it later, cut out more expansion kits.  
All DXF files are in millimeters  
Update for R2 - Cut either of the R2 Base Units, and then as many Expansion and Top kits as you want for additional bays. The base unit makes one complete section, and an expansion and Top set are needed for each additional bay. R2 does not require glue, but can be glued for sturdier construction.

comments.text: Awesome design.  I'll probably be adding on more expansions soon.
comments.author: chilnic

comments.text: the files should be in mm. the wood thickness was 3mm, so the smaller dimension of the rectangles near the edges should be 3mm.
comments.author: jampedalea

comments.text: Does anyone know why these DXF's will not import into Visio. I have tried using Trueview and now AutoCAD to export them as working DXF's or DWG's and neither work.

One of my Bonsai trees needs a bigger planter... so i made one my own.

In this package you will find two different bonsai bowls in 3 different versions.

Currently printing on my printer... photos will follow.

Update:
Added some trays in different sizes for the round version.
140mm, 120mm, 100mm.

Update 2:
Added some additional try for the oval version.
200x140mm, 180x120mm

Update 3:
Added an optimized version (*-V2.stl) of the round bowl 140mm diameter with less filament needed for printing and more space for earth inside.

1. Choose the bowl you want.

  2. If it is a version without feet then also choose some feet.

  3. Print all models.

  4. Glue the feet to the bowl as you like.

  5. choose a tray and print it.

  6. if you want feed for the tray, choose some and print them too.
    Glue the feed to the tray.

Printing:

  • no support needed (except the version with feet included)
  • 15 - 100% infill
  • PLA or ABS usable

title: Arduino Mega 2560 r3 bracket for Extrusions I-Type 5 slot - Horizontal version

description.text:
While building the aweseom http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:811271 I needed a way to attach my Arduino Mega 2560 r3 + Ramps, but no good bracket presented itself for some reason.

The ones I could find had holes that didn't line up and/or were overly complicated.

My sourceprinter also couldn't print it in one piece so I've split it in two and joined the pieces with a simple m3 8mm flat-headed screw and a single m3 nut.

The 1-piece model without center-bracers is available here too.

Update 1. september 2015: fixed some minor error.
Added a vertical version of this over at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:993526

I printed 0.2 layer height and 20% infill. Plenty strong.

You can print either the 1-piece model, which doesn't have the connecting braces in the middle, or print the 2-pieces bracket.

You need 2 plastic-zippers for the two top holes (see photos, on how to orient them) and 2 M3 8mm screws. I used hexagon socket screws.

BOM
2x M3 8mm hexagon socket screws.
1x M3 8mm flat headed screw (for the 2-piece version)
2x plastic zippers.

To fasten bracket:
2x M3 8-10mm screws.

Here's my entry for the #FilamentChallenge a complete redesign from my first attempt, I hope you like it!

Unfortunately my 3D printer is still in the post and will be until after the closing date of this competition so I have been unable to print this out to check if it works. If you like the looks of it please feel free to print it out and let me know what you think and how it can be improved.

You will need (for the basic model):
4x Part 1 (Legs)
4x Part 2 (Rollers)
2x Part 3 (Joiners)

Optional Extras:
Part 4 (Filament Guide)
Part 5 (Double Leg) - for multiple spools, I recommend that joiners are printed to a length specific to your spools such that the split is in the middle of the double leg, alternatively multiple joiners can be linked with part 6. 4 additional rollers should be printed per double leg.

The legs, double legs, and rollers have unavoidable overhangs and should be printed with supports.

There are holes running through the legs and rollers which will accept a length of 1.75 mm filament (or a length of metal wire might be better).

The filament guide has holes for both 1.75 and 3 mm filament, it also doubles as a filament filter with the addition of a piece of sponge and lubricating oil.

I wanted a stand that would hold the iPad Air 2 both in Portrait (with home button accessible) and Landscape. (You can of course flip the iPad and have the Home button on top, but it's nice to be able to insert it both ways). I usually flip it when it requires charging.

Based on my design for the iPad 2/3/4 Stand:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35091

Download "xxx_test.stl" where xxx is the base filename. These are CUT versions using NetFabb Studio for the slot size. As everyone's printer is different, once you determine which slot best fits your iPad Air 2. Download the full STL that matches the "_test" version. I've included what I use (6.3mm) as well as .1mm, .2mm, .3mm larger slots.

Files attached: iPad Stand Air 2.stl -> Slot is 6.3mm, after which additional files: 6.3mm+.1,6.3mm+.2,6.3mm+.3

Printed at .27 layer height, 10% Infill, No Extra Shells (2 in total) on a Replicator 1 using ABS. Print, wait to cool, remove and insert iPad :) Depending on your retraction settings you may want to smooth out/wet sand the slot where the iPad goes so not to scratch it.

Holds the iPad in Portrait (with the home button accessible) or in Landscape.

Originally designed using Tinkercad: https://tinkercad.com/things/lKTfNYRyg0a-ipad3-the-new-ipad-stand?

comments.text: I printed one of these originally pushing my Anet A8 to the extreme, in regards to speed and high layer height. It somehow broke at the front where the base of the Ipad lays, snapping just above the Ipad logo. I think my son put his kindle in it, and applied leverage. Now I'm printing another at a lower layer height and slower speed. 4.5 hour print. Great functional design. I'm using version 6.3.1 for my Ipad 2.  I've thought of designing my own, with the inclusion of the Ipad 2 Sound deflector. I can use both when its laid horizontally, but not vertically.

description.text:
I have for some time wanted to get a new desk lamp, but i have not been able to fine one that i liked and that used led's so i decided to make my own, so here it is.

There is a picture with some red parts that show some different versions of parts and print settings.

Se instructions for print-settings and material's used.

Print one of all the parts.

My print settings:
0.1 mm layerhight, PLA filament, 210 nozzle temp, 60 bed temp, 30 mm/s print speed, simplify3d slicer, 1 mm support pillersize(silplify3d setting), 30 deg support angle, From bed support, 100% infill.

I have also added a block to help drill into the tubes.

Parts
14x m3 10mm countersunk screws (7 cut down to 4-5 mm)
3x 10mm 1m long alu tube
1x 30x15mm 1m long L-shape alu profile

the alu parts did a buy at a local hardware shop.

description.text:
Here is a DRAFT (work in progress) attempt at a hot tub jet. So far I have printed it (CTC dual replicator clone) but have had so much scaffolding / support the end result isn't good. Initial print was in PLA but acknowledge ABS would be required in a hot tub.

Would welcome thoughts on how to improve the printing of threads and open apertures.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hgDR71DULL4

I would have preferred to have scanned this item and then printed but current scanners have issues with an item like this 9hollow all the way through).

Hot tub is a no name import into UK. Spares are very expensive hence my trying to make more.
Drafted in TinkerCAD. Dimensions were taken off original part using digital calipers. Printed on CTC repliicator. Threads are based on metric threads found modelled in TinkerCAD.

comments.text: Tips for abs on CTC turn bed to 130 in makerware as that will only just be enough to print abs and is actually about 90c if you want to fix this solder a replacement 100k thermistor to the bottom of your heated bed and that will fix the hbp temp as the one ctc put on the machine is wrong
comments.author: iCloud

description.text:
UPDATED with an additional smaller size, plus a drumstick.

A nice sounding hand drum made out of a single printed piece.
https://youtu.be/AQqfMECkWJY

This is sized to fit on an Ultimaker 2 -- 200mm diameter, 50mm deep.

I've also made and tested a version sized at 150mmx50mm. It works great, has a higher pitch than the big one.

You can't scale this file. It will change the wall thickness and or the skin thickness and it won't work right.

Also I've uploaded a nice hand drum stick. It makes a much louder and cleaner sound than hitting it with knuckles.

The two I made were done in ABS plastic, not sure how it will perform in other materials.

To play it, hold in one hand as show in the photo, rap it with the knuckles of the other hand. It makes the best sound if you hit it at the opposite edge from where you are holding it. Or use the drumstick and hit it in the center.

When you slice this make sure that the "skin" is made of at least 2 layers. The skin itself is .5mm thick. In Cura I set the initial layer to .3mm and the remaining layers to .2mm This gives two crisscrossed layers for the skin.

Use at least 50 percent fill.

I have a glass build platform on my Ultimaker 2. To be sure it does'nt lift while printing i use some glue stick on the platform, plus printed with brim.

Let it cool completely before attempting to remove. It should come off with almost no effort.

You can see in one photo I have stripes on one. I did this by manually pausing and changing colors. Each stripe took 20 minutes of printing to get their thickness.

handDrum.stl is the original file... Thingiverse doesn't let you rename a file , so I uploaded a new version of it: handDrum200.stl so it's explicit that it's the 200mm version.

Update:
I've uploaded a 150mm sized one... Plus a nice drum stick that works well with both drums.

When you print the drumstick, you should print with brim because it prints vertically and the brim tends to support tall thin things well. If you print at 50 percent fill it comes strong and has a nice weight to it.

comments.text: Please leave a comment to let me know how the drum worked out for you... or click "I made one"

title: Microphone cover for Flightcom GA headset
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My dog (Oscar) decided to eat my aviation headsets. In particular he nibbled the microphones. Most of the innards are OK, so what I needed were new plastic mouldings to house a small PC board and the condenser microphone.

Only complete microphones are now available (retailing anywhere from $55 to $85 per unit), hence my being keen to find a self help solution.

Your wiring and connectors may be different to you may need to re-model how the wiring interacts with the mic.

You can see one half of the old black microphone in the pictures.

I printed this in PLA and it works well. Suggest you use the V2 file.

Wishing you VFR weather!

I modelled the solution in Tinkercad and then printed a series of prototypes until the electronics fitted OK inside the print.

Place mic and PCB in print, then test the headset. Use super glue to glue the top on.

Please treat this item as being a 'work in progress'.

description.text:
UPDATED!!!

2017/07/25: Wow! Sorry I've taken so long and been so quiet (you should see my blog!) but...life happens! I've uploaded the new version of the spool holder that is a single interchangeable piece, so you just print four of them and you're good to go! I put the old version in a zip for safekeeping so Thingiverse wouldn't auto-generate images for those objects anymore. I'll be updating the assembly drawing soon!

Other changes made to the design: Went from inch to metric, so I rounded out the dimensions just a little. And I removed an unnecessary hole that was doing nothing but adding perimeter-printing time.

Previous Update
2017/02/01: I've been meaning to do this for a while, but I've had a lot of projects going on, as part of my return to actively designing for Thingiverse, I'm going to update my first (And very popular!) Thing.

First and foremost, I'm going to remake it in Fusion360, because I'm transitioning over from Inventor. But I'm also going to incorporate the very common sense feature included in dara's remix design; namely, making a single part that can be used as A or B...I don't know how I didn't think of it, I handle lots of items designed like that every day! Don't worry though, that'll be it, it'll be basically identical, just without the need to print two different parts. These are still fantastically simple spool holders, and I still use mine!

Original Text:
This is a spool holder I designed out of necessity back in March, not long after I got my printer. I consider it to be the first 'real' part I made. Print two sets of parts for one complete spool holder. You will need FOUR common 608 bearings, a.k.a. 'skate bearings'.

It uses standard bearings that most Makers probably already have a drawer full of and that makes the spool rotate super-smooth. It's also relatively fast-printing, and you can get away with printing it at as low a resolution as you'd like to make it go faster. (I'd recommend not skimping on infill though.)

It should fit any spool, so long as the flange of the spool isn't thicker than the width of the bearing... And out of 8 different spool types I have, I haven't found one that didn't fit. (Even a mini spool wasn't small enough to bottom-out between the bearings.)

Printer:

CTC-3D Dual Extruder (Bizer)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm or larger

Infill:

15% or more. Triangle or hexagon/fast-hexagon pattern recommended.

Notes:

IMPORTANT: If your printer doesn't print dimensionally-accurate parts, you're going to have a bad time. The bosses are 8mm OD, to match the ID of a 608 bearing, and the mating holes are 7.9mm ID... So if your slicer has an 'Horizontal Size Compensation' setting (Simplify3D) this would be the time to use it if you need to...

There aren't any real fine details, so feel free to print this at the biggest layer height your printer and material can handle. I wouldn't recommend going any finer than 0.25mm just because it'll increase print times and all the layer ridges might make it harder to press fit stuff.

Triangle pattern infill is great for truss-like structural parts like this.

How it came about...

I was putting my printer on 14-inch deep wire shelving, but it would only fit without the filament spools mounted on the back. I decided the thing to do would be to mount the spools on the shelf above, and run the filament down to the printer...so I'd need to make spool holders!

For one complete spool holder you need to print and assemble two sets of parts, and you will need four common 608 bearings.

  1. Print four duplicates of the part. (Version 5)

  2. Press-fit 608 bearings onto bosses on each part.

  3. Press-fit the halves together. (Should also be a tight fit, might not get them apart again.)

  4. ???

  5. MAKE COOL THINGS!

comments.text: One of the nicest types of spoolholders! I'm printing 12 sets (thats 12 x 4 ). Can fit 10 on my buildplate.

title: Greg's Wade extruder easy adapter for printing with Filaflex

description.text:
Utilizando 2cm de tubo PFTE podrás imprimir con filamento flexible sin hacer ninguna modificación en el extrusor.
--
By using 2cm PTFE pipe you will print Filaflex with your Greg's Wade extruder.

Nada de lo que hay que hacer precisa de ningún tipo de habilidad especial. A la vista está en las fotografías el acabado de mi "adaptador".
1.- Corta un trozo de 2cm aproximadamente de tubo PFTE para filamento de 1,75mm.
2,- Haz una muesca en el tubo, con un cúter o una lima, hasta el centro del tubo. La longitud de la muesca ha de ser del diámetro del extrusor (más o menos 9mm)
3.- Introduce el filamento en el adaptador
4.- Cierra el tensor sin apenas apretar el tubo PFTE
Fin

It doesn't requires great skills. Look at the pictures and you will see it.

  1. Cut an approximately 2cm PTFE pipe length (1.75mm filament)
    2 - Make a notch in the pipe. The length of the notch must be aprox. the diameter of the extruder (about 9mm )
  2. Enter the filament into the adapter and then into the hole of the extruder. The filament must be in contact with the screw M8 " Hobbed - Bolt"
  3. Close the idler loosely PTFE tube
    Go to print!

author: CallJoe

description.text:
This is an SVG file created in Inkscape that can be used to create a zoetrope.  There are 21 slats that need to have images placed on them.  
You need a laser cutter with at least a 12 inch by 24 inch bed.  This design uses any material which is about 6 mm thick.  I use Midwest Plywood 24x12 inch poplar plywood (6mm thick).  However, I suggest getting baltic birch plywood.  It's about a $1 more per sheet but I think it will look a lot better.

To finish it, you need: 1 8mm x 20mm bolt
1 8x22x7 mm ball bearing (used for skateboards and rollerblades)
1 8mm bolt
1 washer, 8mm id, 10-15mm od Remove the seals from the bearings. These will slow the rotation down. There are 5 main parts. These are :

  • Small ring. This one is about 50mm outside diameter with a 22 mm inside diameter. It goes around the ball bearing. The bearing will probably need to be pounded in with a rubber hammer. Be gentle. Doesn't take a lot of force. Make sure one side is flat with the wood.

  • Small circle. This is about 192 mm outside diameter with a 20 mm inside diameter. This is the base platform. glue the small ring onto this so that the ball bearing rests on the ledge created by the 22 mm and 20 mm cutouts.

  • Large ring. Approximate outside diameter is 212 mm and inside diameter is 192 mm.

  • Large circle. Approximate outside diameter 212 mm and inside diameter 7 mm. Put the bolt through the base with the head of the bolt on the bottom. It should go through the middle of the ball bearing. Place the washer on the bolt so that it rests on the top of the bearing. Screw the large circle onto the bolt. Place nut on end of bolt protruding through large circle.

  • Slats. Place slats into grooves in large circle. Cap with large ring. Spin and enjoy!

This a sunflower shaped design for a door stop wedge that you can download free from Thingiverse and print out for free using your (or your friend's) 3D printer. V2 Update 12/7/11: Half moon sphere modified flatter sphere, making it easier to 3D print! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OGv9F1IE-Uk
Download the .stl, process the gcode, press print, use on doors required to be wedged open and stop them from inconveniently closing.
This pure love is the basic constituent of the life.
Simply two parts prints and stick together.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1088024

This is a OpenSCAD file for making a spool holder out of a Lazy Susan bearing. The tri-slot middle is so that you can fit multiple custom spool adapters if you swap between different brands of filaments.

I'd decided to design this after reading an Instructible about using a Target Lazy Susan spice tray as a spool holder...
http://www.instructables.com/id/The-10-10-minute-Filament-Holder/

Unfortunately I ran into (and thought of) a few problems:

  • At $10, (update, it's now up to $15!) it was a bit much
  • My local Target didn't have that tray in stock. (http://www.target.com/p/chefs-tool-crock-oak-turntable-lazy-susan/-/A-16943689#prodSlot=medium_1_2 )
  • It wasn't guaranteed to fit perfectly like that every time for the many different spools out there.
  • There is no way to center the filament spool on the wooden disk.

However, the current stl on this "thing" is for a 4-inch bearing purchased at ACE Hardware. It cost me around $5 and it was in stock at a store near my workplace.

http://www.acehardware.com/product/index.jsp?productId=3463597

With ABS I had to scale by 1% (1.01 multiplier) because of shrinkage.

(TODO: Due to the difficulty of making this align with the bearing, I need to re-release this again with a slotted screw hole for "fudging" the tolerances. Note: Carefully rotate/align the nut traps.)

The screws and nuts are typical m4 hardware.

The .scad file is provided for you to customize for your spools and bearings! I highly recommend AGAINST printing these pre-compiled stls!

More detailed instructions soon....

  1. Get a caliper, a small Lazy Susan bearing (with square flanges/plates), and some m4 screws and nuts... (I say small... like four inches...)
  2. Measure the center points of the screw holes for your Lazy Susan bearing. (This is annoying if you're in America... inches don't translate well to mm in this case)
  3. Measure the inner diameter of each spools' bore.
  4. Edit the OpenSCAD file accordingly. Export to stl separately. //TODO: Describe each variable that needs to be edited!!! Also, describe how to render each part separately with slash-slash comments!
  5. Print the parts. The Bearing/Plate adapter might shrink, (depending on your material) so that might require a few iterations to get right as you scale it on your printing software.
  6. Place the m4 nuts in the nut traps.
  7. Screw/bolt the bearing to the plate adapter.
  8. Screw/bolt the plate adapter to the spool adapter.
  9. Mount the bearing to a large wooden block as a base. Add rubber feet for friction. Screw on an eyelet as a filament guide if necessary.
  10. Throw out your excessively large vertical spool holder that lacks bearing(s).
  11. Get on with printing more stuff without the fear that your spool tower/holder is going to topple over.

title: 28BYJ-48 Gear for Camera Slider
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This gear was designed to work with the shorter shaft of the 28BYJ-48 stepper motor for a camera slider project. It should also work for most other machine belt applications too as it offsets the shorter shaft and adds an extra 2mm for better belt tracking on a 6mm GT-2 belt design. The gear should be printed at 0.2 Layer height, 30% infill (min) and think shells. Also worth note is printed with out support and it works, but the upper lip isn't so pretty but function and think it was better then having supports stuck to the gear. Another thing to note is the fit is VERY tight so I used a heat gun to warn the shaft (do not burn yourself, its easy to to do) to heat it and pressed it in. This makes for a very tight fit, in addition you could also use JB Weld too as keep in mind it has to be tight as you are placing a lot of force on that shorter shaft.

For more information, visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com for latest builds!

author: mdroman

description.text:
When I had to replace the old and used crank set of my daughter's bicycle with a new Shimano FC-M591 44/32/22, I realized too late that the big chain ring it came with did not have mounting holes for the chainguard. So I tried to find a commercial chainguard which I could somehow fit via the 4 mounting screws of the chain ring - but could not find anything reasonable. Thus, I finally ended up designing and printing such a chainguards myself...

The chainguard consists of a thinner outer ring, a thicker inner ring and inner arms connecting the chainguard to the chain ring mounting screws, which are usually 4 or 5 hollow screws located on a circle with 104mm diameter. These chain ring mounting screws consist of an outer barrel with an inside thread and a hollow inner screw which has a 5mm Allen hex key cavity on the outer side and a 4mm hole going through all the way. While it would be possible to attach the chainguard directly with these screw assemblies, I don't think that this would be reasonable, since these screws bear a lot of force and need to be fastened very tightly - no good idea to squeeze any lastic in between...

So we need to somehow use the hole inside these mounting screws to attach the chainguard. The easiest way (but not so elegant) is to use countersunk M4x20 screws from the inside and use an M4 nut as counterpart on the outside of the chainguard. A more elegant solution is to cut an inner M5 thread into the hole of the screws, so that we can the just use M5x16 Allen key bolts from the outside to firmly mount the chainguard. For this you need to first slightly enlarge the holes using a 4.2mm drill bit and then use an M5 tap cut the inner threads.

The SCAD file is fully parametrized. The main parameters are

  • the number of teeth of the big chain ring (T)
  • the number of mounting screws (H)
  • the radius of the circle on which the mounting screws are located (R)

Ready-to-print STL files are provided for some of the standard configurations, using 42/44/48 teeth and 4/5 mounting screws. The files ending in nt use M4 with outer nut traps, all the others are for M5 bolts and tapped threads.

Since it was easy to do, I have also included an STL file with a chainguard for a 44 tooth chain ring which has 4 standard mounting holes for the chainguard on a 155.5mm circle.

Note that the 44 teeth chainguard will just fit in the standard 200x200mm printing region, while the 48 teeth version need an extended printing region of at least 205x200mm.

I printed the chainguard on my DIY box-frame Prusa i3 using a 0.40mm nozzle with 0.25mm layer height and 0.56mm extrusion width. I print on a clear mirror without Kapton tape but thoroughly cleaned with acetone and double concentrated lemon juice.

The supports under the bridge at the crank position need to be teared off after printing. Also the screw holes have a bridging layer inside, so you will need to re-drill the screw holes with a 5mm or 4mm drill (the latter for the nt versions) before mounting the chainguard,

comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: Did you change the values in the corresponding call to module chainguard()?  If you just change the default value given in the module definition, then this value will only be used when no corresponding parameter is passed as the module is called, which is not the case in all the predefined modules ChainGuard_XXXmm_TYYzzz().  I suggest that you create your own new module ChainGuard_XXXmm_TYYzzz(), make the parameter changes in there, and the at the very end of the file call that module and comment out the one which is currently there.

A cheep and simple magnifier for close up or through-hole soldering.

printed on DA Vinci 1.0

This is a very preliminary design that came about by necessity.

I have been prototyping for my new project and was looking for a powerful magnifying aid.
All of the magnifiers i looked at were very expensive and not of the magnification i was looking for.

I built the whole thing for less than 20 GBP and am very satisfied with the results.

The magnification is powerful and the led lighting works great.
Surface mount components are easily re-workable due to the power of the lenses.

BOM-things you need to make this thing are as follows.

3x 100mm magnifying glasses. x5 magnification
eBay item number:351381904152

1x 100mm led ring light-12 volts
1x 12 volt power supply 140ma minimum
2x ipad stands with flexible shafts and ball joint swivel brackets,eBay item number:
281891938508

Print out the round holes STL and nut cut outs STL x 2 of each to make up the two halves of the clamping brackets.

8x M5 nuts and bolts [email protected] 60mm and [email protected] 40mm are used to fasten the two pieces together sandwiching the ball joint of the i pad stand between them.

This design is very flexible in its placement,it can be mounted rear or front of work table or even under a shelf.

The mounting clamps move around the ring of the magnifying glass to enable easier positioning of the lens to the work piece.

update coming soon

enjoy

PS my wife stated it looks like something out of the Matrix hence its name.

This is an edit of "Money Clip" by Bre. I made a few edits to the original to fit my needs.
  • I tapered the clip to allow it to hold fewer items. It has a nice solid pinch now.
  • I flared the lips on the outside to make sliding cards/cash into the clip easier.
  • I increased the clip height to keep it from sliding around quite so much.
    • This is my first derivative, I had a lot of fun tweaking an existing model to suit my needs. I posted the evolution of the clip on my blog here: http://www.thenewhobbyist.com/2011/07/with-thingiverse-youre-never-designing-alone/ Now someone download this and make it even better! Edit: Added v4, This is taller and has an even more extreme angle on the top clip. This is a huge improvement for me. Try this one first if you're looking for a really solid clip. New Museum Challenge notes: This money clip is a derivative of an original model by Bre Pettis. My v4 clip is the fourth iteration of Bre's design. The Money Clip v4 is a simple wedge clip that can accommodate 5-6 credit/business cards as well as a small fold of cash. The clip also features a curved outer lip to simplify returning cards to the clip. The printed ABS allows for enough flex to firmly hold the contents of the clip while also allowing for expansion when necessary. I believe it is a great example of collaborative design. I have been using this 24/7 since my derivative was uploaded and it has proven to be very rugged and sturdy showing no signs of wear. So in addition to the money clip showing how collaborative editing can improve the design process it also makes a good case for the day to day functional use of a home 3D printer.

• Print money clip
  • Clip money

author: BARDOUL

title: Stratux ADS-B, Single-band, w/ AHRS/GPS provisions
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This holds all of the components (except power source) to keep your Single-band Stratux ADS-B nice and organized. Now includes provisions for GPS/AHRS component!

Dual band case is here!

Print one of each half of the case. Case was modeled in inches, so you will need to scale mm to inches. Dimensions are 6.25" x 3.5" x 1.5".

I recommend printing in PLA. Infill used on my prototypes was 17% with 2 shells. Low or medium resolution is fine for the lower case. Medium or more is recommend for the upper case, as well as support structure.

Stratux reddit threads are here: Pt 1, Pt 2.
See also the Stratux subreddit for ongoing discussion and development.

As of 9/2/15, upper case now includes provisions to mount the GPS/AHRS chip. This will require 2 to 4 of the screws (same size as mentioned below for the R Pi. GPS chip needs mounted with the GPS antenna (largest white square) facing the sky, that is, the inside of the upper case. Wiring is DIY at this point as I have not integrated this component into my build yet. See the picture up top for suggested orientation.

For the RTL-SDR antenna, place its base in the circular "corral" on the lower case. Route the antenna wire to coil in on itself between the Rasperry Pi standoffs. Make sure it stays in a single layer so as not to touch the Pi's PCB. Leave about 4" exposed towards the non-antenna side of the case. This will connect to the radio dongle's antenna input.

You will need a short (6"-8") USB A male to A female extension to connect the radio dongle to the Raspberry Pi. I used this but the exact model isn't important. Attach it to the Pi before you mount it to the lower case. You will also need at least one screw to hold the Pi to the case's standoffs. As long as the screw fits through the Pi's mounting hole and is shorter than the case's standoff, it should be fine. I used a spare from my computer parts kit.

Carefully snap the radio dongle into its mount and attach the USB extension.

Note: The case does not house a power pack. Adhesive-backed Velcro nicely attaches your choice of power pack to the case.

Apply power and go fly!

Features:

Closed-case access to...

  • Micro USB (power)
  • HDMI
  • TRRS

Other...

  • Antenna folds flat
  • Micro SD card accessible when case open
  • Case can be opened by hand, but a house or car key is easier
  • Radio dongle sits snugly in clips
  • Antenna held down when case halves are mated

title: Biohazard MakerBot Spool Holder for small spools

description.text:
A Makerbot inspired Bio-hazard Spool Holder. I will not be able to print this design out for a few days due to my printer still in the hands of ups. I will print this out and show a video of it in use, if it functions well. If it does not function properly i will remake this completely or make some modifications.
Thank you everyone for downloading or viewing my project! it really means a lot to me!

Before you start, choose which size you want. Walls are the same, however, the length of the "connector_spool" and "connector_floor" are different sizes. The regular size kit is 150 mm long. The other sized kit is 118 mm long. Make sure if you want the 118mm only print the parts with "118mm kit" at the end of the file name, besides the wall.

  1. Connect the "Connector_spool" to the "wall".
  2. Place the "Connector_spool" through filiment spool hole.
  3. Place the end of the "Connector_spool" through 2nd "wall".
  4. Place the hexagon connectors on "Connector_floor" inside the holes at the bottom of the two walls.
  5. Enjoy!

Number Of Parts Required

  • 2 "wall"
  • 1 "Connector_spool"
  • 1 "Connector_floor"

title: Da Vinci 1.1 Cartridge Touch screen programmer

description.text:
I further developed the available online code to allow easy programming of the eeprom from a cartridge via a touchscreen. The touchscreen shield was purchased from eBay which had the SPFD5408 chip. I've included the arduino code and needed libraries.

You will need:
Arduino Uno
Touchscreen 2.4 shield with SPFD5408 chip
Spare Eeprom chip from cartridge
DPDT switch like the one pictured
Wire and Soldering iron etc.

How I installed it:
I removed the back panel and took 5v supply (pos and neg) and feed the cables to where the programmer was going to be installed and wired to power the arduino ( wired the neg through the DPDT switch so the arduino is only powered then the eeprom is connected to the arduino). I then carefully soldered 3 wires to the place where the eeprom cartridge is read (Pos / Signal / Neg). The pos and neg was soldered directly to the spare eeprom which is housed with the touchscreen. The signal is soldered to the DPDT switch. Pin 4 on the arduino is then also wired to the DPDT switch and finally the centre position of the DPDT switch is soldered to the eeprom. This then allows the DPDT switch to toggle the eeprom to Connected / Off / Arduino.

comments.text: OK another question, does the cartridge need to be in constant contact with the eeprom or can you just reset the cartridge separately and then just place it back in the printer by itself?
comments.author: tezz

comments.text: the eprom in the drawing is soldered to the switch, then wires are routed and attached to the small board in the printer where the cartridge makes contact.  when the switch is in position 3, it simulates haveing a cartridge installed, so you don't want a cartridge installed into the printer when using the reprogrammed chip.  if you want to use a DaVinci cartridge, you put the switch in pos. 1 which disconnects the programmer from the printer, and you print normally.   So in practical work, if you want to use factory cartridge, put switch in pos 2, insert cartridge and use as normal, if you want to use other filament, take cartridge out, put printer screen in the main menu mode, place switch in position 1, set the parameters you want, hit save, switch over to position, place switch in position 3, now printer is reading programmed chip, load filament using screen as normal, just keep factory cartridge out of printer while using programmer chip.
comments.author: tezz

comments.text: It will stay in each position.  the center(2) position disconnects the programmer from the printer,  Position (1) turns on the UNO for programming, and position (3) the other end connects reprogrammed chip to printer.
comments.author: tezz

comments.author: Im_batman

comments.text: If I'm reading your statement right, this doesn't read info from another cartridge chip, you are programming the chip isolated in the programmer case.  I wouldn't have a cartridge installed since you could get some cross data corruption.  when you need to program the chip installed in the case, set the switch to program mode(screen is on), put the printer in home screen.  I press the ABS then PLA just to be sure it takes, set the desired bed and extruder temps, then spool length, seems if you select 400 it will report something like 400m left of 1m.  tap the save button, the screen should blank for a second.  on my unit the switch is in the far right position(call this position 3)  in the center(ie 2) it is disconnected from the cartridge reader down in the printer.  the far left position (i.e.1) that connects the chip in the case to the printer.  switch the switch from 3 to 1 and now the settings should be seen by the printer.  go to the filament screen on printer and it should show your new readings.  if you put the switch in the ctr position the programmer and chip are isolated and you can use a factory spool with it's own chip.  if needed I can make a quick video to show what I mean.  but if I'm using the programmer with the chip that is soldered and interfaced in the case I will not have a cartridge installed.
comments.author: Im_batman

comments.text: It will but will most likely require different screen drivers so you will to alter the code. It's nothing major and I can talk you through how to do it. There are a few different types of touchscreens and each have a different driver chip so it might take you a couple of tries to find the correct driver for yours.  The arduino comes with a sample LCD touchscreen code which you can load in to test.. ie paint program etc.. Once you find which is right if you let me know then we can alter the code to suit. Most likely then we will need to work out where the buttons are then on the screen in relation to where you touch. This is just a case of adding a couple of lines of code and monitoring it in the serial connection monitor which is part of the arduino software. So you touch bottom left of the button and then the top right. Then add these figures into the code.
comments.author: DarkTreader

comments.text: What firmware version are you using with the filament resetter?  I am still waiting for my unit to arrive, this and the MK8 mod are high on my list.  THanks for all your work.
comments.author: DarkTreader

comments.text: I'm using the firmware that came with it but not running WiFi on my printer just run it on USB. I found if I run on WiFi it must do some online checking with the filament serial or something.
comments.author: DarkTreader

comments.text: is there something specific about the Audrino that everyone uses it, I have a RaspPi and don't see anyone using these for any of these functions..
comments.author: CdRsKuLL

comments.text: I think it's because its easier to get your head around. You don't need to load an OS at all you just connect it up and upload code to it. No SD cards are required.   It's slow compared to the pi but they are great for a hobby board with a massive following and help via forums etc is always on hand.  I've used them for loads of things and only being a few quid great for projects.   :-)
comments.author: DarkTreader

comments.text: are there instructions on doing wiring and software install included in the download files?  I'm a bit rusty on the programming half, will be ordering parts soon to start this and the MK8 mods.  Thanks for the rapid response, Xmas is a bad time to order tech gear.  I ordered the 1st and Dell is back-ordered hope to get on the 28th.
comments.author: CdRsKuLL

comments.text: I don't think there is.. I can take photos / draw diagrams for you etc and offer any help you need to get it working.  For the mk8 mod you only really need the centre bit. I used the motor / fan off the standard one.. Just all bolts together.
comments.author: DarkTreader

comments.text: I finally got my 1.1plus on the 30th,  when you have a chance could you zap over any photo's/diagrams for the programmer. looking forward to unlocking some of this printers potentials.
comments.author: CdRsKuLL

comments.text: anything would be great thanks, really excited to get going.  with taking the 1.1 off wifi, are you able to use the built in camera?
comments.author: CdRsKuLL
